contentrichtext.text: {| align="right" cellpadding="4" style="border: 1px solid #aaaaaa; margin: 0 0 10px 10px; padding: 10px; font-size: 36pt; line-height: 40pt; text-align: center;" | Ʒ ʒ |- |Ʒ ʒ |} '''Ezh''' ('''{{unicode|Ʒ ʒ}}'''), has its small letter used in the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]] (IPA), representing the [[voiced postalveolar fricative]] consonant. It is also called the "tailed z". Example: ''vision'' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|v|ɪ|ʒ|ən}}. It is pronounced as the "s" in "treasure" or the "si" in the word "precision". (See also the [[Persian alphabet]] letter [[Že|ژ]] and the [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Zhe (Cyrillic)|ж]].) Ezh is used as a letter in some orthographies of [[Skolt Sami]], both by itself, and with a [[caron]] ({{Unicode|[[Ǯ]] ǯ}}). These denote partially voiced alveolar and post-alveolar [[affricate]]s, respectively, broadly represented /dz/. It also appears in the orthography of some African languages, for example in the [[Aja language (Niger-Congo)|Aja language]] of [[Benin]] and the [[Daghbani]] language of [[Ghana]], where the uppercase variant looks like a reflected sigma ([[Sigma|Σ]]). ==Origin== {{further|tailed z}} As a phonetic symbol, ezh originates with [[Isaac Pitman]]'s alphabet in 1847, as a ''z'' with an added hook. The symbol is based on [[Gothic minuscule|medieval cursive]] forms of Latin [[z]], evolving into the [[blackletter]] z letter. In Unicode, however, the blackletter ''z'' ("[[tailed z]]", German ''geschwänztes Z'') is considered a glyph variant of ''z'', and not an ezh. In contexts where "tailed z" is used in contrast to tail-less ''z'', notably in standard transcription of [[Middle High German]], Unicode {{unicode|ʒ}} is sometimes used, strictly speaking incorrectly. Unicode offers {{unicode|[[ȥ]]}} "z with hook" as a grapheme for Middle High German coronal fricative instead. == Ezh as an abbreviation for dram == In [[Unicode]], a standard designed to allow symbols from all writing systems to be represented and manipulated by computers, the ezh (alternatively '''ℨ''') is used as the symbol to represent the abbreviation for [[dram (unit)|dram]], an [[apothecaries' system]] [[units of measurement|unit]] of [[mass]]. == Ezh and yogh == In Unicode 1.0, the character was unified with the unrelated character [[yogh]] ({{lang|ang|Ȝ ȝ}}), which was not correctly added to Unicode until Unicode 3.0. Historically, ezh is derived from Latin [[z]], while yogh is derived from Latin [[g]] by way of [[insular G]]. The characters do look very similar, and do not appear alongside each other in any alphabet. To better differentiate between the two, the [[Oxford University Press]] and the [[Early English Text Society]] extend the uppermost tip of the 'yogh' into a little curvature upward. == Ezh and the digit three == The capital ezh looks similar to the common form of the [[3 (number)|figure three]] (3). To differentiate between the two characters, Ezh includes the sharp zigzag of the letter z, while the number is usually curved. Still, there is a slightly different form of the Arabic numeral three called banker's three, which looks like the ezh. Its origin is that bankers did not want forgers to turn the 3's in a check into 8's, so the top is angled. == Ezh and hiragana ro == [[Image:ろ-bw.png|thumb|right|280x60px|Stroke order in writing ろ]]Ezh looks similar to [[Ro (kana)|ろ]], the Japanese hiragana letter for the [[Mora (linguistics)|mora]] "ro". However, the central corner of ろ points out further away to the left than that of ezh. Furthermore, the hiragana for "ru" is る, appearing identical to ろ except for the spiral at the end. == See also == * [[Abkhazian Dze]] (<span style="font-size:190%;">Ӡ ӡ</span>) * [[Ze (Cyrillic)|Cyrillic Ze]] (<span style="font-size:190%;">З з</span>) == External links == * [http://www.evertype.com/standards/wynnyogh/ezhyogh.html On the derivation of Yogh and Ezh] {{Latin alphabet}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Z - Ezh}} [[Category:Palaeographic letter variants]] [[Category:Phonetic transcription symbols]] [[Category:Uncommon Latin letters]]
